          Hi! Welcome to my page!
          I am a Ph.D. Student at the Economics departement (BSE) of the
          University of Bordeaux in France.
          
          I am currently involved in the NEEMSIS project of
          the Observatory of Rural Dynamics and Inequalities in South
          India (ODRIIS),
          hosted at the French Institute of Pondicherry (IFP), India.
          
          Check below the making-of of the NEEMSIS survey!

articles.title: Project
articles.contents:
Contents
Observatory
of Rural Dynamics and Inequalities in South India

Observatory
of Rural Dynamics and Inequalities in South India
Coordinated by Dr
Isabelle Guérin and Dr
Christophe J. Nordman, the ODRIIS Observatory is housed by the
research program “Household vulnerabilities, labour and socioeconomic
dynamics” in the Social Departments of the French Institute of
Pondicherry. ODRIIS aims to analyses how structural changes in
contemporary India are reshaping the organisation of work, social
hierarchies and household livelihoods. The observatory combines
different tools through a collection of projects to help understand
these socio-economic changes under different lights. We have been
collecting quantitative panel data on households and individuals in
rural South India via the NEEMSIS Survey. We also use a variety of
socio-economic methods (financial diaries, village monographs, life
stories, video documentaries, etc). Beyond the regional analysis, the
ODRIIS Observatory intends to contribute to the theoretical renewal of
the concepts of work, networks, skills, debt and financialisation.



Figure 1: Family from Manapakkam, India.

articles.title: Research
articles.contents:
Contents
In progress
Publications in
peer-reviewed journals
Reports

In progress
Natal, A. Psychology of Debt in Rural Tamil Nadu, India
(Preliminary draft). Bordeaux, France: University of Bordeaux.
Using a panel dataset built from an original household survey
carried out in 2016-17 and 2020-21 in rural South India, we analyse the
relationship between personality traits (conscientiousness, openness,
extraversion, emotional stability, agreeableness) & cognitive skills
(Raven matrices, literacy and numeracy scores) and financial
decision-making. We focus on the recourse, the negotiation, and the
management of debt. We find that certain personality traits such as
openness, extraversion, and conscientiousness are generally
significantly associated with negotiating and managing debt. The
magnitude and statistical significance of the association between
personality traits and debt differs across castes (Dalit, non-Dalit) and
sex. These findings suggest the use of personality traits and cognitive
skills for females as a way to overcome the weight of social identity in
a rural caste-segmented patriarchal context.

Natal, A. & Nordman, C.J. Measure and (In)stability Over
Time of Cognitive Skills and Personality Traits in Rural India
(Preliminary draft). Bordeaux, France: University of Bordeaux.
Natal, A. & Nordman, C.J. Persistence of Over-Indebtedness
in Rural India (Preliminary draft). Bordeaux, France: University of
Bordeaux.
Publications in
peer-reviewed journals
Guérin, I., Michiels, S., Natal, A., Nordman, C. J., &
Venkatasubramanian, G. (2022). Surviving Debt, Survival Debt in Times of
Lockdown. Economic & Political Weekly, 57(1), 41–49. Full
article available here.
Reports
Nordman, C. J., Guérin, I., Michiels, S., Natal, A., &
Venkatasubramanian, G. (2019). NEEMSIS Survey Report: A Full
Statistical Picture of the Household and Individual Data (Survey
report). Paris, France and Pondicherry, India: French Institute of
Pondicherry (IFP) and French National Research Institute for Sustainable
Development (IRD). Retrieved from https://neemsis.hypotheses.org/ressources/statistical-report
